title: Protective and damaging effects of stress mediators
summary: Describes how chronic activation of the body’s stress response (allostatic load) damages cardiovascular, metabolic, and immune systems over time, explaining the long-term cost of living under constant pressure.
supports: Long-term pressure and stress load have cumulative effects on the body
Short bursts of stress are tolerable, chronic activation is harmful

title: Job strain as a risk factor for coronary heart disease: a collaborative meta-analysis of individual participant data
summary: Shows that high job demands combined with low control over work are linked to an increased risk of coronary heart disease, especially relevant for men in high-responsibility roles.
supports: Job strain with low control is physically harmful
Perceived control over work load is a key factor in long-term health

title: Stress signalling pathways that impair prefrontal cortex structure and function
summary: Explains how stress chemicals weaken the prefrontal cortex, leading to more impulsive, short-term decisions and reduced self-control under pressure.
supports: Stress narrows thinking and pushes people toward fast, reactive decisions
Restoring calmer states supports better judgment and impulse control

title: Men, masculinity, and the contexts of help seeking
summary: Examines how traditional masculine norms around toughness and self-reliance make men less likely to acknowledge strain or seek support, increasing the risk of silent overload.
supports: Masculine norms can delay men from addressing damaging levels of pressure
Reframing help-seeking as responsible action increases engagement
